section.title: Equation
section.para: This was created using the July 2, 2008 build of GMAT.

section.title: Overview
section.para: The Equation command uses the Equation to make one variable equal to some combination of previously defined variables and values. It is highly useful for storing values so that they aren't lost. Additionally, it is very useful for advanced commands.

section.title: Listing of Objects and Commands that interact

listitem.para: The standard box for Propagate and other commands, the box can select variables that can contain values which were established using the Assignment command. Additionally, the parameters listed can be changed using the Assignment command.
Most often used in conjunction with the Assignment command, the variable object is set up to store values.

Can be used in conjunction with the Assignment command so that one spacecraft can take on the characteristics of another spacecraft. This technique is useful for storing conditions of a particular spacecraft before the values of the spacecraft are changed through Target sequences and Propagate commands.

This is where the variable that will be taking on a new value is typed. It can never be a value, but generally will be a variable or spacecraft. If it is a spacecraft, this is the spacecraft that will be changing its old conditions.

This is what the variable/spacecraft is set equal to whatever is placed in this box. The right side can contain variables and values. It can also contain any of the math operations listed in the Math Operators in Scripting under the Reference-Misc menu in GMAT Help.
